I need to make another confession.
Throughout this book, I’ve said that the developers should be the bottleneck. No exceptions. Timer Teams, hourglass shape, every time.
But I’ve been telling Eve’s story at conferences for years—and her team actually broke that rule.
Why? What was different?

Everything I’ve told you so far assumes that you can choose where your bottleneck sits. Most teams can. You can hire more developers, or more testers, or more analysts. You can redistribute capacity. You can reshape.
But sometimes you can’t.

Eve’s team was an exception. They weren’t building new products—they were fixing regulatory bugs in ancient code. And their real bottleneck was testing—for reasons you’ll see shortly. There was no way to increase testing capacity. It was fixed. Immovable.
If Eve had made developers the bottleneck, her testers would have had spare capacity—which means they’d have done less testing. Total output would have dropped.
So she did the opposite. She accepted testing as the bottleneck and reshaped everything else around it.
It’s not a Timer Team. But the thinking is the same.

Several years ago, a CIO called Alfonzo asked me to speed up one of his software teams. He said the team was made up of the company’s oldest, cleverest, and gnarliest programmers, and their job was to fix the oldest, ugliest, and gnarliest bugs in their old, ugly, gnarly code base.
The team of 16 was trying to eliminate 112 regulatory defects. Alfonzo had promised his CEO they would get that number down to single figures by the end of the year.
It was late April, so they had just over eight months left.
“They need to get through at least thirteen a month,” he said. “They’re currently doing ten. That’s a 30 percent bump in productivity.”
I asked if he had a backup plan.
“I’ve got a big project wrapping up in September. If I need to, I’ll move six of my best programmers onto these bug fixes.”
More developers. The obvious solution. I nodded and went to meet the team.
Their manager, Eve, showed me around. When I asked to see their defect tracking system, she pointed behind me to three whiteboards covered in yellow stickies—one for each defect.
“You said you have two testers. Where’s their board?”
“They have their own board, around the corner.”
“How come?”

“Once upon a time, the testers’ stickies used to fit on the third board along with the programmers’. But the testers couldn’t keep up, so I got them a new board. It would block the walkway if we placed it next to the others.”
She wheeled out the fourth board and placed it beside the others.
The four boards showed the team’s entire process. Each defect went through four steps: Analysis, Design, Programming, and Testing. What struck me was where all the work was stuck.
The testers’ board was packed. I stepped closer and noticed the stickies were grouped into three clumps: one huge, one small, and one medium.

Eve explained: “The big clump on the left—those have been fixed by the programmers and are waiting to be tested. The small clump is currently being tested. The medium clump has been tested and is waiting to be shipped.”
I counted roughly forty stickies in that big clump on the left. At ten defects a month, that was four months of work just sitting there, waiting.
I drew an imaginary red circle around it in my mind and labeled it the Waiting Room.
“That big clump reminds me of patients sitting in a hospital waiting room,” I said.

Eve snorted. “If it were a waiting room, they’d all be dead by now. Died of boredom.” She plucked one sticky from the pile, turned it over, and blanched. “The programmers started working on this defect fourteen months ago.”
“Fourteen months?!”

“It’s easy. The programmer takes two weeks to fix it. As soon as they’re finished, it moves to the testers’ board, where it sits in the Waiting Room for a few months. When the testers finally look at it, they discover that it’s mostly fixed but not completely. So it goes back to the programmers’ board, where it waits again. When the programmer becomes free, they fix it again, and it goes back to the Waiting Room for another few months.”
She grimaced. “Do you see where this is going?”
I did. For most of those fourteen months, the defect was just sitting around waiting to be worked on.

The testers were the bottleneck. They couldn’t keep up with the rest of the team. But because everyone else kept working at full speed, they’d created that enormous Waiting Room—and ridiculous delays.
I asked Eve if there was any way to get more testing capacity.

She shook her head. “Our two testers are already working as efficiently as possible. They’ve cut every ounce of fat they can find. Neither has had any training in the past two years. They never attend their test-team meetings. They cannot do any more.”
“What about recruiting?”

“Our old, clunky system is staggeringly difficult to learn. Whenever someone new joins, my existing testers slow down enormously because they have to teach them. It takes months and months to get up to speed. There are only four testers in the whole company with the depth of knowledge we need, and their managers won’t release them.”
She folded her arms. “So there you go.”
A week later, I met with Eve and her entire team in the boardroom. We’d carried the four whiteboards up—it took two elevator trips.
I explained the bottleneck situation. Eyes glazed over. So I changed tack.
“Have you guys heard the buffalo joke?”
It's an old joke—an imagined conversation between Norm and Cliff from the TV sitcom Cheers.
The gist: a herd of buffalo can only move as fast as its slowest member. When wolves hunt them, they pick off the weakest at the back. This makes the herd faster and stronger.

“In much the same way,” Cliff explains, “the human brain can only operate as fast as the slowest brain cells. And as we know, alcohol attacks the weakest brain cells first. So, regular beer consumption eliminates the weaker brain cells, making the brain faster and more efficient. And that, Norm, is why you always feel smarter after a few beers.”
There was a burst of laughter. Then everyone looked around, smiling at each other. Then they turned back to face me, clearly wondering why I’d just told them this silly story.
I asked: “Do you folks have a slowest buffalo in your team?”
All eyes turned to the two testers, Lawrence and Anne, sitting at the end of the table.
Anne said tentatively, “Obviously, it’s us, right?”
One of the senior developers, Peter, chuckled. “Does that mean we should feed you two to the wolves?”
Everyone laughed—including the testers.
Then Peter turned serious. “I know you’re both working really hard, but is there anything—anything at all—you can think of that might help you speed up, even a little bit?”
Lawrence shook his head. “We’ve been asking ourselves that for months.”

But Anne said, “Actually, there is one thing. You guys keep interrupting us to ask questions about the defects you’re working on. That takes time away from testing, and after we’ve helped you, it takes us a few minutes to get back up to speed. If we weren’t interrupted so much, I bet we’d gain half an hour back each day.”
Peter frowned. “But if we don’t ask you for help, we can’t finish our work.”

The team’s designer, Gloria, spoke up. “Isn’t that the other point of the buffalo joke? The faster buffalo needs to slow down and run at the speed of the slower buffalo. Otherwise, the herd splits apart.”
Silence.
They’d been trying to fix their problem by having everyone work harder. Now they were realizing that the faster buffalo needed to slow down.

Eve spoke. “I’m going to make this easy. Starting now, no one works on any stickies unless they’re already on the testing board. There’s at least three months’ work there. Those defects are our only priority. Don’t start anything new.”
One programmer protested: “But we can’t just sit there doing nothing!”
Peter said, “We don’t have to twiddle our thumbs. Some defects will fail testing, and we’ll need to fix them. And …” He turned to the testers. “Are there any ways we could help you out?”
Lawrence thought for a moment. “You could type in some of our test data. That takes us ages.”
Another programmer shook his head. “I’m not doing manual data entry. We’re programmers—we automate things like that. We’ve got scripts written that you could use.”
Lawrence stared at him. “You’ve got scripts?”
“Of course. Hasn’t anyone ever shown you?”
“No!”
“I guess we’ve been too busy.” The programmer paused. “I can customize and run them for you. It’ll save you a load of time.”

The conversation kept going. The programmers offered to take over environment management so the testers could focus on testing. The analysts offered to sort through the Waiting Room and group similar defects into batches. The designer offered to identify which defects would be hardest to test, so they could leave those for last.
By the end of the meeting, the whole team was working differently.
Almost a year later, Eve and I had lunch together.
“We fixed and tested 106 of the 112 defects,” she said. “Hit Alfonzo’s target. We bumped our throughput by a little over 30 percent without spending a penny.”
“Brilliant!”
“A year ago, it used to take over ten months from when an analyst first looked at a defect to when we shipped it. Now it’s down to five weeks.”
“Fantastic!”
“And remember how Alfonzo promised to lend us six developers if we needed them?”
I nodded.

She chuckled. “Turns out we had too many programmers. I reduced my headcount and gave three to projects that could use them. So not only did our throughput jump by a third, but my budget dropped by 15 percent.”
I asked if testing was still her bottleneck.

She frowned. “Of course. Where else would it be? We keep a few stickies in the testers’ fuel tank, ready for testing. Not too many, not too few. We couldn’t do that if our programmers were the bottleneck.”
She smiled.
“My team is calmer, happier, smaller, and faster than we’ve ever been.”
Eve’s team wasn’t a Timer Team. They couldn’t be. But they used the same thinking: find the real bottleneck, stop fighting it, and reshape everything else to support it.
Remember Alfonzo’s backup plan? Six more developers. The obvious solution.
It would have been a disaster.

Eve’s team didn’t have a developer shortage. They had a developer surplus. All those programmers churning out fixes that piled up in the Waiting Room, sitting there for months. Adding six more would have made the pile bigger and the delays longer.
The problem wasn’t too few developers. It was too many—relative to their immovable testing capacity.
Once Eve saw that, she did the counterintuitive thing: she slowed the developers down, used their spare capacity to help the testers, and eventually gave three of them back to other projects.
Fewer developers. More output. Lower costs. Faster team.
Sometimes the answer isn’t more. It’s less—but in the right shape.
